name: 1975 Chateau Giscours
text: The “confident ease” of this wine begins to spread the moment I lift my glass. A 39-year-old vintage may no longer have a young face, yet its composed and graceful posture remains captivating. The light smokiness and pine fragrance create a profound yet refreshing complexity; with mature tannin powder massaging the palate, it leaves my palate brimming with joy.

name: 1975 Chateau Giscours
text: 92-94 Looks like a 15, actually 45 years Bordeaux, cedar with some red fruits nose are really elegant and noble, your nose cannot stop but enjoy this quite unbelievable  complex sleep beauty. Still a bit grippy, it tasted like date and haw juice with short sweet finishing. January 27, 2020

name: 1985 Chateau Cos d'Estournel
text: Fully developed, the nose, with its spice box, tobacco leaf, forest floor, and cigar wrapper calls your name. Medium-bodied, fresh, vibrant, round, and packed with dark currants and red plums, this is ready to go. If you have a bottle, there is no reason to hold this any longer. It will not improve.

name: 1985 Chateau Cos d'Estournel
text: The most prominent character of Cos 1985 is the finesse and freshness. Although this wine is not highly intense, the grapes’ ripeness is just perfect. Scents of the forest floor are lingering around the classy leather and tobacco, like a warm melody of Cello around my body. What impresses me the most is the unforgettable freshness from the inside out, which is an excellent expression of Bordeaux’s elegance.

name: 1985 Chateau Gruaud-Larose
text: Fully mature, the seductive nose offers hints of truffle, tobacco, spice box, licorice, blackberry, cedar wood and smoke. Smooth and round with a little dust in the tannins, the wine ends with a sweet and sour cherry finish.

name: 1985 Chateau Gruaud-Larose
text: The aroma of the 1985 vintage encompasses a rich array of aged herbal notes, revealing that the ripeness of the Cabernet Sauvignon did not reach its optimal level. Though the fragrance may seem a bit tired, the palate showcases a “old tough guy’s” character, with a consistent acidity and a unique wild leather flavor complementing each other. The body of this wine is somewhat thin, with a hollow structure that lacks a bit of “fleshiness”, making the tannins stand out more. Fortunately, the wine has a very smooth mouthfeel, ending with a hint of sweetness. It is recommended to open the bottle and enjoy it now.

name: 1985 Chateau Gruaud-Larose
text: (1997) Very full, deep crimson colour. Leafy cabernet nose, hint of toasted oak and burnt rubber. Medium bodied, very pure, clean blackcurrant fruit and soft, integrated oak. Nice long, peppery finish with firm tannins. Good length. Just below my top 3.

name: 1989 Chateau Giscours
text: The color is a deep, dark, ruby-red. The nose is an intense combination of red-plum & raisin fruit. Initially the palate shows notes of tobacco-leaf & raisins overlaying delicate red-fruits. acidity is good & fresh. The structure has a medium weight with a pleasant depth of fruit. Alcohol is balanced & the finish lasts reasonably well. 11/93 DCAMW

name: 1989 Chateau Giscours
text: Light crimson and tea in color, the wine offers earth, tobacco, cassis, barnyard and cherry flavors. With a short, red fruit finish, this is beginning to dry out. Consumers should drink this sooner than later.

name: 1989 Chateau Giscours
text: The 1989 vintage’s maturity is genuinely appealing. I believe that anyone who encounters this wine will instantly feel its charming smile and a reassuring strength. The rich, roasted aromas of walnuts and hazelnuts don’t dominated the vibrant fruity notes of cherry, bayberry, and blood orange. The mature, savory character of beef jerky and the spicy notes of Sichuan pepper climb in a spiral towards the finish, adding layers of richness and intricate details. I can see the image of a sunny boy in this 35 years old wine, if you’re looking to experience the warmest embrace of Chateau Giscours from the 1980s, the 1989 vintage is, unquestionably, the best choice.

name: 1995 Chateau Giscours
text: The 1995 vintage, with its 60% Merlot composition, feels a bit softer and less powerful than what I typically associate with Chateau Giscours. The palate is round and soft, with fine tannins. The aromas of raspberry and strawberry juice remain vibrant, complemented by the scents of resin and matsutake, creating a lively profile. From my understanding of the 1995 vintage, Chateau Giscours isn’t best suited for prolonged aging but is more enjoyable if opened now. Recommended drinking window: 2010-2030. (40% Cabernet Sauvignon, 60% Merlot)

name: 1995 Chateau Giscours
text: Crème de cassis, tobacco, earth and cherry aromas, medium bodied with some tannin to resolve, this lighter style of Margaux ends with a cassis and strawberry finish. This is the first vintage for Alexander van Beek at the chateau. The wine was made from a blend of 60% Merlot and 40% Cabernet Sauvignon. The wine is fully mature and will not improve with further aging.

name: 1997 Domaine de Chevalier
text: Strong carmine garnet, broad ochre rim. Tobacco, damp undergrowth, some dried plums, a little damp wool, a delicate bouquet. Slender, some currant, fresh acidity, mineral, delicately leafy savouriness in the finish, remains short. (Drinking now).

name: 1997 Domaine de Chevalier
text: If I had to choose a wine from a cooler vintage that shows how good Domaine de Chevalier is, I’d pick the 1997 vintage. Even though this vintage has noticeable signs of being underripe, it doesn’t feel out of place in this wine. Good weather during the harvest in September and October seems to help a lot. It has a robust fruit smell, a nice tight mouthfeel, and soft tannins. After being aged in the bottle for a long time, and it’s got even richer with a nice herbal scent and, with a touch of cedar, tobacco, and mocha powder. Now, it’s time to taste it.

name: 1998 Domaine de Chevalier
text:
Cherry red with white rim. Timid nose, green fruit, cherry, oak, 60min later, the wine is opening up. Suave and sweet, red fruit, cabernets are ruling the taste, cherries, blueberries. Needs time in the glass (best decanted).
Very good but not great.

name: 1998 Domaine de Chevalier
text: Medium to deep, ruby-red in color. Medium to full intensity of leafy cassis & cedary oak aromas have a slightly agricultural character. Cassis & redcurrant fruit on the palate is supported by lively acidity. There is a lovely medium to full bodied structure that combines suppleness & grip. Alcohol is balanced & the acidity lifts clean red-fruit, giving a long finish. 11/02 DCAMW

name: 1998 Domaine de Chevalier
text: Fully mature, the wine is medium bodied, elegant, soft, fresh and charming. The tobacco, smoke, cherry, earth and cigar box aromatics are right where it needs to be. Feminine, with more on the nose than on the discreet palate, this is ready for consumption. 90 Points

name: 1998 Domaine de Chevalier
text: Strong ruby colour, broad brightening on the rim. Blackberryish fruit, subtle undergrowth note, fine oak nuances, some liquorice underneath. Full-bodied, blackberries, dark cherries, a hint of ripeness, elegant, fine tannins, mineral, salty touch in the finish, still very youthful, lemony aftertaste, a pleasant food wine, has really matured over time. (Drink/+10).

name: 1998 Domaine de Chevalier
text: It’s really cool how this wine manages to be both juicy and sweet, and also strong and muscular at the same time – it’s like combining two opposites in one drink, which makes me so excited. With the mature vintages of Domaine de Chevalier, you can really use your imagination. Take the 1998 vintage, for example: it’s like a charming, polite knight in shining armor, and riding a tall horse. It’s like the ideal image of a “Chevalier” – just perfect! If you have this vintage in cellar, you can keep it for more than 15 years without any worry.

name: 2000 Domaine de Chevalier
text: The strength of the 2000 vintage of Domaine de Chevalier made a good impression on me. Even after 23 years, it still has a proud character that can’t be worn down. I am happy to find ta kind of freshness hidden inside its strength and maturity, like there’s a bit of sadness behind its impressive look. So, compared to the typical hot vintages, I don’t think the 2000 Domaine de Chevalier is very typical. But this ‘gentleness behind the strength’ really struck a chord with me.

name: 2000 Domaine de Chevalier
text: Medium to deepish ruby-red. Powerful aromas of plummy red fruit are well-married with oak notes. Ripe, plummy fruit on the palate is medium to full bodied with attractive cedar notes. Acidity is balanced to good & alcohol is in check. Tannins are fine & supple, giving grip on the finish, which lasts well. A well balanced wine with the concentration to age well. 11/04 DCAMW

name: 2003 Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou
text: Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou’s interpretation of the 2003 vintage showcases the poise and composure of a top-tier estate when faced with challenges. Despite the unexpected heatwave, this wine exhibits a wonderful freshness. The robust aromas of mint-infused dark chocolate and juicy blueberry, coupled with hints reminiscent of “Xiao Qinggan” and Pu-erh tea, exude both maturity and a unique, fragrant blend of orange peel. With its strong and well-structured body, accompanied by a delightful lingering “sweetness” on the finish, it is undoubtedly a rare gem of the 2003 vintage.

name: 2003 Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou
text: On a rapid evolutionary track, you already find secondary notes of wet forest floor, tobacco leaf, red spicy berries and smoke. The wine is round soft and polished, with a tobacco, spicy, red berry and mocha tinted finish. I would drink this over the next decade or so.

name: 2003 Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou
text: This is a solid, powerful wine packed with tannins and heavy black fruits. As so often, Ducru is taking its time, and this wine is still knitting itself together. But in future years, watch for the generosity, the richness as well as the finesse and freshness. Imported by Diageo Chateau & Estates.

name: 2004 Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou
text: Impressively dense, dark flavored wine, very rich and quite extracted. But it still keeps the elegance and some of the freshness of 2004, and there is plenty of blackberry flavor to push the wine along. Heavier than many 2004s, it still shows that great acidity.

name: 2004 Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou
text: Ready to drink, stylish, soft, sweet and inviting, the wine is equally attractive in its earthy, berry and tobacco scented nose as it is in the fresh, spicy, fruit filled finish.

name: 2004 Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou
text: The pronounced aromas of mocha and truffle dominate the 2004 vintage, while the glass reveals ripe plums, red cherries, and a subtle touch of refreshing pine after swirling. During a blind tasting, I found it to resemble a commendable 2008 vintage rather than the relatively straightforward nature of 2004. In my opinion, Ducru-Beaucaillou’s meticulous craftsmanship in taming the tannins and expressing a delicate hint of salinity contributed to its success in the challenging 2004 vintage, setting it apart from numerous wines of the same year.

name: 2005 Chateau La Tour Figeac
text: The 2005 vintage of Chateau La Tour Figeac boasts a strong structure and firm muscle. The hot, dry weather didn’t weaken it; instead, it forged a robust physique. Clear aromas of caramel, preserved plums, and dried prunes greet the nose, and swirling the glass reveals complex spicy notes of licorice, cinnamon, and clove. This wine has a magical hint of salinity that unexpectedly highlights the sweetness of the Merlot, reminiscent of the “Sucre & Sale” concept in French cuisine.

name: 2005 Chateau La Tour Figeac
text: (2007) Quite subdued aromatically, but with a fine, dense, tight fruitiness. The palate is muscular and dense, with a chunky black fruit quality that is chewy, with a certain plummy breadth and mouth-filling ripeness. Again, no shortage of structure in a wine that is perhaps less fine that the best.

name: 2005 Chateau La Tour Figeac
text: The entry is plush, rich and soft. Aromatics were enough to keep me interested, but, I'd like to see this wine in another 5 years to learn how well the oak bonded with the wine.

name: 2005 Chateau La Tour Figeac
text: Very straight, firm, a wine that seems to be developing slowly. The blackberry fruits are impressive, rich and pure, and the tannins form a dense core of darkness. The wood is currently showing too strongly, but the fruit will certainly open out in a year or so. An impressive wine, but it needs time.

name: 2005 Chateau Latour-Martillac
text: 91-93 Barrel sample. With its dryness, this seems at first to be all tannin. There is, though, a black currant fruit flavor that shows through after the wine has been in the mouth for a while, and the aftertaste has fine acidity. This should develop well.

name: 2005 Chateau Latour-Martillac
text: The taste of the pencil shave of Latour-Martillac 2005 is very impressive, presenting the classic image of the Left Bank Cabernet Sauvignon shown after the bottle aging. The acidity of this wine is higher than my memory of 2005 in Bordeaux, and the texture of tannins is softer and gentler. It brings me an aftertaste of the signature saltiness of Latour-Martillac and the warm note of tobacco that lingers on a yuppie man’s fingertips. This is a very masculine left bank blend.

name: 2006 Chateau Cantenac Brown
text: Forest floor and tobacco coupled with blackberries are found in the nose. The wine is fresh, medium/full bodied and finishes with a crisp cassis note, coupled with an herbal streak. The wine was made from a blend of 75% Cabernet Sauvignon and 25% Merlot and was aged in 60% new, French oak barrels. Only 30% of the harvest was used in the Grand Vin. 90 Points

name: 2006 Chateau Cantenac Brown
text: Unlike the greenness about the vintage of 2006 in Bordeaux, Cantenac Brown 2006 expresses a pretty mellow nose. The ripe blackcurrants and red cherries are embraced by a layer of cedar and resin’s freshness, calm and elegant. It is the first vintage that they adopted “intra-parcel selection” during the harvest (they started from the outside of each parcel and finished the core at last). Although the Grand Vin only accounts for 30% of the total production, the quality is unquestionably impressive. The smooth taste and soft tannins end up with a touch of graphite-like texture. This wine is at its drinking peak.

name: 2007 Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou
text: A very powered wine, pushing forward with solid, but always fresh structure and fruit. The wine bursts with ripe jammy fruits, but is also firmly tannic. It combines sweet weight with final extreme, exuberant freshness.

name: 2007 Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou
text: Fully mature, medium bodied, with silky tannins, freshness and soft, polished textures, the wine is on the spicy, red fruit side of the style range. Quite nice for the vintage, this is not a wine I would hold for more development. If you're sitting on any, I'd pop a cork to enjoy the fruits before they fade.

name: 2007 Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou
text: The aromatic profile of this wine may not be particularly pronounced, but the refreshing essence of cedar is rather pleasant, emanating notes of cranberry and preserved plum upon swirling the glass. I can feel that the team waited until the very last moment to harvest. The palate is light and smooth, with a bright and elegant acidity, while the cedar and mushroom aromas resemble a lively melody. Against the backdrop of modest fruit intensity, they awaken dormant taste buds with their natural charm. I recommend enjoying it now.

name: 2007 Chateau Haut-Bailly
text: Dark ruby, purple reflections, subtle ochre brightening on the rim. On the nose, subtle animalistic notes, a touch of dark berries, hints of tar and background notes of ripe cherries. Juicy and fresh on the palate, subtle fruit expression, red currant, salty-lemon hints, a savoury note and a lasting finish. A lively, well matured yet uncomplicated food companion. (Drink, store +15)..

name: 2007 Chateau Haut-Bailly
text: Elegance and freshness are the main topics of Haut-Bailly 2007. Although the weather condition was not ideal this year, HB tried its best to demonstrate harmonious beauty. The nose is very supple; it features more graphite and pencil shave character thanks to 70% of Cabernet Sauvignon. The entry of the palate is purely straightforward, coupled with minty freshness and ultra-slim tannins from head to toe.

name: 2008 Chateau Brane-Cantenac
text: Showing its age in the color, the developing nose offers wet earth, espresso and red fruits. The wine is medium bodied,, with barely a tannic edge remaining to the sweet cherries on the palate. Just a few more years will add even more softness and complexity to the wine. The wine was made from blending 70% Cabernet Sauvignon, 28% Merlot and 2% Cabernet Franc. 91 Points

name: 2008 Chateau Brane-Cantenac
text: After 13 years of aging, this wine is still very vigorous. The moderate nose is purely precise, offering cranberry, sour jujube, and Chinese hawthorn. The palate is soft and sleek, with bright acidity and Brane-Cantenac iconic silky tannins towards the finish.

name: 2009 Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou
text: Intense hue, crimson highlights. Great depth on the nose dominated by black berry fruits, liquorice sweet and subtle, slightly spicy oak. Dense, well-structured, monumental palate, still a little backward. Hugely successful effort. Keep… for a long time.

name: 2009 Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou
text: Ducru mixes 75% cabernet sauvignon and 25% merlot. The nose was cool and fresh showing green olives a bit of Brettanomyces and meaty notes with more of that French oak smoke and toast. The palate is lean and sleek with fresh black fruits and some healthy tannins. The finish is firm and dry not showing much. Perhaps all these Bordeaux are in shut down mode for the next three years. The group scored this wine 1st overall with 92 points. Parker gave it 100 points. Clearly some controversy here. Wolf Blass Master Blend Classification Montreal. (Anthony Gismondi and Stuart Tobe).

name: 2009 Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou
text: The aromas of Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou 2009 have evolved more rapidly than I thought. While the predominant scents still consist of luscious blueberries and ripe plums, hints of cigar box, pine nuts, and a cool hearth are already emerging. This wine artfully presents the maturity of a hot vintage in a refreshing and natural manner, as if finding a respite under the shade of an oak tree on a scorching summer day. It not only perfectly embodies the personality of Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou but also showcases the invigorating quality that develops in aged Cabernet Sauvignon. If the tertiary aromas continue to evolve delicately without undergoing significant changes, it will undoubtedly become an exceptional wine of remarkable distinction.

name: 2009 Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou
text: Deep and dark in color, fruits are equally dark. Powerful, full-bodied, rich, opulent, and fresh, the layers of blackberries, plums, espresso, flowers, earth, cigars, and spice seem endless. On the palate, even though the wine is incredibly dense, it is also seamless, elegant, vibrant, pure, and expansive. While approachable now, if you want the full experience, allow it a few more years in the bottle and enjoy it over the next several decades. Drink from 2025-2055.

name: 2009 Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou
text: Dark ruby garnet with purple reflections and a delicate brightening at the rim suggesting some maturity. The nose is still somewhat closed, with hints of fine woody savouriness, ripe wild berry fruit and orange zest. With air, dark cherries and a touch of nougat slowly emerge. The palate is complex - juicy and pronounced in fruit, in particular ripe cherry, with fine and very well integrated tannins. A mineral-salty finish has very good length. There's clear further ageing potential here, for decades even, but already it seems relatively light-footed thanks to its perfect balance. It can already be opened, but should ideally be allowed to age for another five to ten years.

name: 2009 Chateau Durfort-Vivens
text: 2009 Durfort Vivens is medium ruby. Blackberry and cassis scents fill the nose of this medium bodied wine. Although it has fresh, attractive flavors, the wine lacks concentration and structure. Made from a blend of 74% Cabernet Sauvignon, 21% Merlot and 5% Cabernet Franc, this should drink well young. 88/90

name: 2009 Chateau Durfort-Vivens
text: Elegant nose of dark berries and tobacco, very elegant palate, slightly lighter than the best examples but with plenty of elegance, freshness and length, dark fresh fruit, soft tannin and very good length, stylish and potent.

name: 2009 Chateau Durfort-Vivens
text: I highly recommend the second wines of the top estates in Bordeaux, especially as the prices of the grand vins make them unattainable for most of us. Vivens from Château Durfort-Vivens is an especially attractive one. Château Durfort-Vivens, classified as a 2nd growth in the Médoc classification of 1855, is regaining its former stature under the guidance of Gonzague Lurton, part of the family whose name implies excellence in Bordeaux. The 2009 Vivens delivers the ripeness of that vintage without being overdone or flamboyant. Enrobed in the plush tannins that are the signature of Margaux, it is “forward” and easy to enjoy now, yet has adequate structure so it doesn’t come across as a “fruit bomb.” It finishes with a hint of earthiness that adds complexity.---- Michael Apstein

name: 2009 Chateau Durfort-Vivens
text: Upon the first sniff, one is drawn in by the refreshing tobacco and tart bayberry aromas; the 14-year-old Chateau Durfort-Vivens 2009 exudes a subtle hint of sandalwood and delicate orange peel. While it may lack a grand structure, it maintains a gentle and elegant demeanor. After 14 years of aging, its tannins have become entirely polished. If it could display greater depth, it would be even more remarkable.

name: 2009 Chateau Durfort-Vivens
text: Deep, dark, opaque ruby-red, holding its color well to the rim. The aromas are strangely volatile & meaty, the wine seems quite mature. The palate is quite closed with restrained red-fruit & a fine structure of lovely seamless tannins. There is good acidity, balanced alcohol and clean, well handled oak. This could open up to be quite a classic Margaux, but currently shows little. 11/13 DCAMW

name: 2009 Chateau Pape Clement
text: Rich and vibrant nose, youthful with dark fruity notes, blackcurrant, cherry, mineral and tobacco, some new oak and coffee beans, very dense and concentrated palate without heaviness, fresh and crunchy with layers of dark fruit a backbone of very fine tannins that adds freshness, fine spices and persistent flavours, very long and lingering aftertaste filled with chocolate and dark berries, seriously structured, already tempting but with huge potential, will develop remarkably well.

name: 2009 Chateau Pape Clement
text: This is a richly structured wine with beautiful perfumes emanating from the bouquet. The rich, stalky texture is balanced by the flavors of dark chocolate and black currant jelly. It's big, ripe and full of potential, a fine balance between opulence and ageworthiness.

name: 2009 Chateau Pape Clement
text: After 13 years of bottle aging, Chateau Pape Clement 2009 has become a piece of adorable black truffle. After shaking the glass, it delivers sweet and mild blackberries, cherries, and layers of hazelnut, which is so beautiful that people dare not take a second glimpse. The mellow tannins caress the taste buds like a cashmere spread between lips and teeth. The generous taste is like a cup of hot milk with cocoa powder, revealing a sense of warmness and a certain “wisdom” in the aftertaste.

name: 2009 Chateau Pape Clement
text: Deep garnet-red. Nose of black berry fruits and toasted notes showing harmony throughout. Powerful, generous and melted at point of entry. Sensation of fullness and power lasting well through to the finish. A harmonious, forceful style.

name: 2009 Chateau d'Yquem
text: 98-100 Barrel sample. The aromas are so rich and powerful, with great ripe apricots. There are honey, spice and beautiful sweet spiced pears. This is an extraordinary wine in an extraordinary year in Sauternes.

name: 2009 Chateau d'Yquem
text: Young, rich, opulent, silky, fresh, vibrant, full, and deep, with enough blazing acidity to allow all the layers of vanilla and honey-coated orange and yellow tropical fruits to bathe your palate again and again with this stunning, sweet treat. OK, so this is still obviously young, and primary, but it is such a delicious experience now, that it was impossible to put my glass down. Patience might be a virtue. But there are times when patience is over rated.

name: 2009 Chateau d'Yquem
text: This vintage grants you everything you want. If one could only taste Chateau d’Yquem for only one time in his or her life, 2009 must be the first choice. Whether viewing from the contamination level of botrytis, the sugar content of grapes, the precious acidity, or its flavors’ complexity, Yquem 2009 can be ranked as an epic. It must be the fruit of human wisdom as well as the gift of God to combine all these elements in the same vintage. I would not bother to describe the aroma and taste of Yquem 2009 here, for it is beyond my competence to portray this unprecedentedly grand banquet on a page. Let’s leave the space for all of “Nectar’s” lovers. If you have the privilege to drink a glass of Chateau d’Yquem 2009, carefully savor the “serenade”, the “Ode to Joy” or the wild “rhapsody” it plays on your palates.

name: 2010 Chateau Clos Saint Martin

Smoke, mineral, licorice, oak, and jammy berry scents open to a supple, ripe, silky textured concentrated wine ends with a long fresh, black cherry, spice and licorice finish. 94-95

name: 2010 Chateau Clos Saint Martin
text: Clos Saint-Martin 2010 displays a subtle touch of oxidation, with pronounced notes of caramel and toffee. This vintage’s acidity is exceptionally elegant, drawing a smooth rainbow-like arc in the mouth, eloquently conveying the concentration and sophistication of the 2010 vintage. The initial “sweetness” harmoniously complements the saline finish, extending across the palate with a tingling sensation of spices. From the wines I’ve tasted, it appears that the 2010 vintage has already reached its pinnacle, and I would recommend not exceeding a further 5 years of bottle aging.

name: 2010 Chateau Jean Faure
text: Compared to the 2009 vintage, I found Jean Faure 2010 riper, more intense, and has greater charm. It is especially beautiful with the black fruit aromas curling in the glass, the smoky tar notes and the graphite scents on the finish. The fresh and cool palate brought by the 55% Cabernet Franc is very pleasing. The whole palate hence becomes light and refreshing, giving you the illusion of flowing in the air.

name: 2010 Chateau La Tour Figeac
text: 2010 La Tour Figeac is made by Christine Derenoncourt, the wife of Stephane Derenoncourt. In 2010, the apple does not fall far from the tree with this wine 75% Merlot and 25% Cabernet Franc blend. Licorice, spice, jammy black cherry aromas open to a suave, lush, fennel, spice and ripe dark berry finish. 91-93

name: 2010 Chateau La Tour Figeac
text: Dark ruby, purple reflections, subtle bright rim. Ripe plum, a touch of liquorice, floral nuances, fine nougat notes. Full-bodied, dark berry fruit, fine vivid tannins, mineral touch, black berry and some nougat in the finish, good length, delicate spicy nuances in the aftertaste.

name: 2010 Chateau La Tour Figeac
text: The 2010 vintage of Chateau La Tour Figeac masterfully combines the richness and warmth of a hot year with the crispness and freshness of a cool year. It boasts sweet aromas of raspberry, cherry jam, and fresh plum, all supported by a calm and composed tannic structure and a breezy elegance. There’s a lovely balance of sweet and saltiness, with strength softened by a gentle touch, much like the Tai Chi concept. This is best vintage of Chateau La Tour Figeac in the past 50 years, offering tremendous aging potential that will impress anyone who tries it.

name: 2010 Chateau La Tour Figeac
text: (2011) Cedary, raspberry-like lift to this, a certain impression of elegance. There's a raciness to the palate, the fruit bright and focused on crisp, bittersweet liquorice and red fruits, with a biting freshness to the finish. Lovely style this, managing the tannins and retaining lots of savoury bite.

name: 2010 Chateau Les Carmes Haut-Brion
text: Just a sniff is good enough to fall you into a sweet world of cream blueberry. Around the flavor of salty dried plum, there is the fragrance of bay leaves and delicate herbal notes. The entry of it, the character of graphite is prominent, with dense tannins running on the palate. The palate of it is intense but well-balanced and elegant. As a wine born in a good year of a century, it will be even better if showing more Phenolic on the finish.

name: 2010 Chateau de Sales
text: The aroma is mature and gentle, effortlessly releasing notes of cranberries, blueberry morsels, and a subtle hint of black truffle without the need for swirling. The presence of mushrooms and a cigar box is pretty good, while the finish carries a trace of metallic dust. The texture is supple, and the structure is delicate, making it well-suited for those who appreciate tenderness.

name: 2010 Chateau de Sales
text: like this, good Bordeaux traits with black fruit and tannins. not as much leather and tobacco as Pauillac and Pessac Leognan, our favourites but still a very good wine at £30 ish a bottle.

name: 2011 Chateau Godard-Bellevue
text: In the 2011 vintage, I sensed an energy reminiscent of a hot year. Its aromas are quite complex, shifting from licorice to meat broth, then from tobacco to caramel. There’s a balance of ripeness and freshness, stability and liveliness. The solid tannins, wrapped in a clay-like body, exude a powerful energy even without swirling the glass. The 2011 Chateau Godard Bellevue is a vintage worth seeking out for wine enthusiasts. From today’s tasting, this wine is even more delightful than the renowned 2010 and 2009 vintages.

name: 2011 Chateau Godard-Bellevue
text: This is a full and ripe wine showing fine concentration, rich and jammy fruits, and some firmer, well-integrated tannins. There is a hint of juiciness as well, leading to a wine that is generous and with some good aging. Drink from 2015.

name: 2012 Chateau Grand Mayne
text: The aroma combination of hawthorn and humidor is very adorable, emitting a distinctive fragrance of sandalwood after swirling the glass. It is pure and juicy on the palate, and the tannins are silky and soft. Although not many changes are found in the mid-palate, this wine is still charming. This wine is a fairly pleasant Saint-Emilion blend (88% Merlot).

name: 2012 Chateau Grand Mayne
text: Medium bodied, finesse expression of St. Emilion leaves you with a soft, silky textured wine, sweet, ripe, juicy cherries and kirsch and a silky, smooth finish. The wine was made from a blend of 80% Merlot, 15% Cabernet Franc and 5% Cabernet Sauvignon.

name: 2012 Chateau Grand Mayne
text: 91–93. Barrel sample. This spicy wine, aged in new wood, is rich and full with blackberry flavors. It's opulent in texture with layers of new oak that reverberate through the wine.

name: 2012 Chateau Haut-Bailly
text: Very firm and closed up, this wine is a tough proposition at the moment. It has the weight to develop well along with richness. Acidity, sweet fruits and concentrated tannins will all come through strongly as the wine matures. Drink from 2020.

name: 2012 Chateau Haut-Bailly
text: Haut-Bailly 2012 is a rare vintage without Cabernet France. In this wine, I can feel two completely contrasting energies; one side is the typical herbal notes of this vintage, like grilled green pepper and asparagus; the other side is intensely concentrated structure. Thanks to Haut-Bailly’s classic creamy texture, these two irreconcilable power unbelievably integrate on the palate, creating a unique harmony towards the finish. So impressive.

name: 2012 Chateau Haut-Bailly
text: Just a super wine, 3 hours of air brought out all its plushly textured plums and blackberries. The smoky essence, with its earthy accents only added to the fun. Full bodied, with round, soft tannins, this is probably the best value for Haut Bailly in the marketplace today. Tasted twice over a 2 week period, once at the estate, and then again ordered off a restaurant menu, this blend of 60% Cabernet Sauvignon and 40% Merlot tasted and felt great!

text: Dark ruby, purple reflections, subtle watery edge. On the nose, sweet tobacco, black fruits of the forest, a touch of orange zest and background savoury herbal notes. Medium complexity, notes of cassis, subtle fruit expression, good freshness and a mineral edge on the finish. Somewhat light-bodied, but offers an uncomplicated drinking pleasure today. (Drink +10)..

name: 2012 Chateau Haut-Bailly
text: Deep, dark, almost opaque ruby red.  Ripe, chocolatey aromas overlay dark fruits. Powerful tannins give good grip but are velvety smooth. Vivid  red-fruit  and cassis aromas harmoniously combine with balanced alcohol and V good length. 11/16 DCAMW

name: 2012 Chateau La Pointe
text: La Pointe is on a roll after their successful 2010. This new vintage is deep in color with coffee bean, licorice and ripe, juicy plums. On the palate, the wine is filled with lush, sexy black raspberries, chocolate and a hint of coffee bean to complicate matters. 91-93

name: 2012 Chateau La Pointe
text: It was a pleasure to taste both the 2011 and 2012 vintages of Chateau La Pointe at the same time. The 2011 vintage is the winner in concentration while 2012 is superior in terms of elegance. The herbal fragrance of sage, kale borecole, and mild thyme creates an ideal freshness in the glass. Moreover, a touch of tannins that are scattered on the taste buds adds some silkiness towards the finish. If more roundness can be added to the aftertaste, this wine will be even more remarkable.

name: 2013 Chateau Les Carmes Haut-Brion
text: Les Carmes Haut-Brion 2013 reverses my impression about Bordeaux wine. It’s the first time I realized that we could play the whole bunch in Left Bank of Bordeaux. 59% Cabernet Franc plus 30% whole bunch seems so weird, but it surprises me a lot once it touches my palate. Though born in such a challenging vintage, it carries no greenness at all. Even the tannins are softer than my imagination. The great extraction technique and light freshness of pine resin offer me the ambition of Guillaume’s entire team, and I am full of expectations for their great vintages.

name: 2013 Chateau Les Carmes Haut-Brion
text: Dark cherry, tobacco and licorice create the perfume. The wine is soft, forward and polished on the palate, with ripe, dark cherries and plums in the finish, making it easy to drink on release. 91 Points

name: 2013 Chateau de Malleret
text: Young garnet. Refined cocoa-like oak backed by ripe currants. A soft, supple and profound Haut-Médoc that is as precise as it is charming. Lovely aromatic balance of oak and fruit framed by fine-grain tannins. A stellar wine.

name: 2013 Chateau de Malleret
text: Compared with other wines from the vintage of 2013, Chateau de Malleret doesn’t have any greenness but a hint of sweetness. After swirling the glass, the gentle nose reveals basil, rosemary, and a hint of pine resin-like freshness. Compared with my tasting six years ago, the tannins at this time are more graceful, coupled with a faint tea stems’ freshness. Overall, a very light wine that is ready to drink now.

name: 2013 Le Dome
text: Initially closed, this wine just hints at its richness and perfumed character. As it opens it shows still-young tannins and intense black plums and blueberries that will develop as the wine ages. It is likely to mature well over the medium to long term, and will not be ready to drink before 2022.

name: 2013 Le Dome
text: Facing a difficult vintage, Le Dome 2013 still maintains a pleasant maturity and easygoing fruitiness. The winemaker must have made a rigorous selection. Sweet and sour waxberry and cranberry are welcomed by a silky and delicate mouth feeling. Although the tannins are slightly noticeable on the finish, the whole palate always maintains an ideal balance.

name: 2014 Chateau Haut-Bages Liberal
text: The estate, under the direction of Claire Lurton, continues its slow regular progress. In this vintage, the emphasis is on the fruit, which is forward and full of black-currant flavors. There is a good medium-term potential to this ripely attractive wine. Drink starting from 2022.

name: 2014 Chateau Haut-Bages Liberal
text: The estate, under the direction of Claire Lurton, continues its slow regular progress. In this vintage, the emphasis is on the fruit, which is forward and full of black-currant flavors. There is a good medium-term potential to this ripely attractive wine. Drink starting from 2022.

name: 2014 Chateau Haut-Bages Liberal
text: Chateau Haut-Bages Liberal 2014 is inexplicably accessible. Both the gentle aromas or the pure flavors are excellent interpretation of the term ‘delicate’. For a vintage produced in relatively mild temperature, this wine shows a good level of ripeness from the inside out. The aromas of crab apple and cranberries are light, emerging like a gentle smile. In my opinion, this is one of the best value Bordeaux wines of the 2014 vintage.

name: 2014 Chateau Les Carmes Haut-Brion
text: Much better from bottle than barrel, this continues developing nicely. Perfumed, silky, elegant and refined, the smoky, dark, ripe, sweet, fresh, red fruits, spice, earth and tobacco linger and build. 95 Points

name: 2014 Chateau Les Carmes Haut-Brion
text: Les Carmes Haut-Brion 2014 impresses me with its fresh and smooth personality, embellished by the fragrance of violet, the flavor of juicy cherry, ripe blueberry, and the freshness of black tea seems to be extremely fresh and elegant. The pure palate creates the illusion of savoring a springy strawberry jelly, with soft and dense tannins and graceful structure melting on the palate.

name: 2014 Chateau Les Carmes Haut-Brion
text: 92–94. Barrel Sample. Dusty tannins float in this impressive wine. It has dark layers of black fruits and acidity that cushion the dry, tannic character, with great freshness at the end.

name: 2014 Chateau Prieure-Lichine
text: Prieure-Lichine 2014 opens up with hints of forest floor and discreet fruitiness. The delicate freshness and mellow body show me an image of a lovely girl next door. The hawthorn candy and cigar box partner is pretty engaging but without much variation after swirling the glass. This wine is more attractive to drink at a younger age.

name: 2014 Chateau Prieure-Lichine
text: This is a concentrated wine, packed with tannins and black plum fruits. It has some of the fruity crispness of the vintage although with its dark structure and concentration it is obviously a wine that needs to soften over time. Rich and juicy at the end, it will be ready to drink from 2024.

name: 2014 Chateau Prieure-Lichine
text: Boysenberry, espresso, black cherry and licorice scents kick off the nose. Medium bodied, with a touch of too much oak at the moment, this needs time to develop, and integrate. While this is already better in bottle than barrel, in time, this should be an even better wine, as it continues to come together. 92 Points

name: 2014 Chateau Prieure-Lichine
text: Dark, medium red-black in color with some color loss at the rim. The restrained aromas have a lifted perfume over cassis, redcurrant & graphite notes. On the palate lovely fresh, mouth-watering acidity helps release perfumed violet & pungent redcurrant fruit. The structure is very fine & almost milky-textured. Wine is medium-bodied, the alcohol is beautifully balanced & the finish is elegant & persistent. 08/22 DCAMW

name: 2014 Chateau Yon-Figeac
text: Chateau Yon Figeac 2014, while not boasting an intense aroma, exhibits a vibrant and refreshing body. It captures the essence of Bordeaux’s traditional aesthetic: precise delineation, elegant contours, and a subdued exterior that hides a gentle core. The subtle notes of cinnamon and star anise gently awaken curiosity and anticipation. This wine has left a lasting impression on me with good freshness.

name: 2014 Chateau Yon-Figeac
text: Medium deep ruby red colour. Fresh nose of plum and red berries, very gentle oak. The palate is medium-bodied with fresh red fruit, rather soft texture and integrated tannin, elegant and classic style that should still develop.

name: 2015 Chateau La Marzelle
text: The 2015 vintage of Chateau La Marzelle showcases an unexpected richness and sweetness with aromas of toffee paired with the palate of milk chocolate. Though this wine has a full-bodied structure, it remains well-proportioned, with finely polished tannin powder that feels like bathing in a soft, velvety black sesame soup. Just as the fine tannins glide over the taste buds, an unexpected hint of salinity emerges. However, it’s important to note that the aroma evolution of this wine is progressing faster than anticipated, so it is recommended to drink now.

name: 2015 Chateau La Marzelle
text: After the ripe, sweet, black raspberries, plum and licorice, you find truffle notes in the background. The wine has density, silky tannins, freshness and a fruity finish that really works. This is already tasty, and it is going to age well too!

name: 2015 Chateau La Marzelle
text: Biodynamically grown, the grapes from this estate offer structure, concentration and a delicious balance between fruit and tannins. The wine has a serious side, with its dense texture and a straight line of pure black fruits. Drink from 2025.

name: 2015 Chateau La Marzelle
text: Bright dark purple core. Lovely purity and intensity of fruit with ripe dark cherry, cassis, some mineral/stony notes, discreet oak and wet tobacco. Very dense palate, harmonious and layered with powdery tannin, a bright freshness underneath the crunchy dark fruit, cassis and cherry notes with a mild spiciness, and a pure intense and very long finish. Very grippy and long with sweet fruit lingering on the palate.

name: 2015 Chateau La Tour Figeac
text: What a delightfully sweet and exuberant wine! It perfectly showcases the mature character of the 2015 vintage while also highlighting Chateau La Tour Figeac’s rich texture. Tasting this wine feels like being embraced by sunshine, with its warmth and energy washing over you. The powdery tannins and silky body complement each other beautifully, and the classic hint of salinity makes it simply irresistible.

name: 2015 Chateau La Tour Figeac
text: This estate, run on biodynamic principles, has made a rich wine with density and intense, pure black-currant fruits. It has a firm backbone of tannins along with perfumed minerality from the Cabernet Franc in the blend. Drink this wine from 2024. Roger Voss

name: 2015 Chateau La Tour Figeac
text: Here's a wine that keeps getting better and better as it ages in bottle. The truffle and floral notes get you going. But perhaps it's the silky, fresh, ripe, sweet, plums and cherries that is the best part. Elegant and classy, this is quite the charmer.

name: 2015 Chateau Latour-Martillac
text: Solid tannins mark this still very young wine. At the same time, the fruit is rich and well proportioned. Black currants dominate the fruity spectrum, giving the wine richness as well as great potential. Drink from 2025.

name: 2015 Chateau Latour-Martillac
text: The 2015 Latour-Martillac has a visible talent. The natural structure of tannins, the pure and mature aromas of sandalwood, and its indescribable aura of mystery show me a Latour-Martillac of excellent quality, making it my favorite vintage of Latour-Martillac without question. Compared with other hot vintages, the 2015 vintage is able to amalgamate the rich and rounded palate with the innate concentration of the clay and gravel soils, leaving an intense and beautiful performance on my taste buds without being cheesy.

name: 2016 Chateau Jean Faure
text: Another Saint Emilion that is better in bottle than it was in barrel, the wine now offers deep, juicy plums, espresso, licorice, truffle flowers. Silky, elegant, fresh and lively, with a lifted, dried red pit fruit and floral finish, give this a few years before popping a cork, and it will show even better.

name: 2016 Chateau Jean Faure
text: Jean Faure 2016 displays some evident notes of graphite and pencil lead, giving you the illusion of being presented with a pencil sketch drawing. Although the fruity aromas are relatively reserved at this stage, its dynamic inner power hidden behind it is still noticeable. The palate is concentrated and intense, with a hint of tar flavors surrounding the fine tannins. Judging from its current performance, I do not think Jean Faure 2016 has shown its true potential yet. With 5-10 years’ bottle-aging, it will perfectly bring out the essence of the Cabernet Franc in good vintage and made with whole bunch fermentation.

name: 2016 Chateau Jean Faure
text: Another Saint Emilion that is better in bottle than it was in barrel, the wine now offers deep, juicy plums, espresso, licorice, truffle flowers. Silky, elegant, fresh and lively, with a lifted, dried red pit fruit and floral finish, give this a few years before popping a cork, and it will show even better.

name: 2016 Chateau La Pointe
text: Dark ruby garnet, purple reflections, faint brightening on the rim. Inviting bouquet with a floral touch, delicate hibiscus, ripe Amarena cherry and touch of tangerine zest. Juicy palate with sweet, but tightly meshed texture, ripe tannins, fine nougat and a very long finish. Certain ageing potential.

name: 2016 Chateau La Pointe
text: The 2016 vintage is a milestone for Chateau La Pointe, a new era for the winery’s entry into high-class Pomerol. This wine perfectly interprets the words “transparent and bright”: the palate is as clear as a stream, the fresh red and black berries burst with sweet juice the moment they touch the palate, and the aftertaste is refreshing with the scent of cypress. Thanks to the intense tannic structure, the wine has a slender body, and you can feel its firm texture when the liquid touch your tongue. It is easy to age for 12-18 years and fans who love Pomerol should pay close attention to this wine.

name: 2016 Chateau La Tour Blanche
text: 94–96. Barrel Sample. Structured and concentrated, this is a rich wine that is also fruity and packed with botrytis and acidity. Its texture and tangy edge are impressive and will certainly allow it to age.

name: 2016 Chateau La Tour Blanche
text: Deep yellow colour. A fine botrytis touch with honey and yellow tropical fruit aromas, and candied orange zest. On the palate juicy, ripe yellow peach, some pineapple and honey, opulent but still harmonious. A versatile wine.

name: 2016 Chateau La Tour Blanche
text: It’s hard to imagine, an elf so unassuming in nose could unleash such a tremendous energy in the mouth. Its bright acidity has the power to transform everything it touches into cloud, into spring; its enchanting orange blossom gives all fruits wings. The 2016 vintage marks Miguel’s first year in charge of the vineyard of Chateau La Tour Blanche. He believes this vintage needs some time to age to become more complete. In my view, this natural presentation aligns perfectly with what the 2016 vintage aims to express: low-key, yet full of hope…

name: 2016 Chateau Montlabert
text: The ripe fruit aromas of the 2016 Chateau Montlabert reveal it as a “child kissed by the sun.” Although ten barrels used “Fermentation Integrale,” the healthy grapes and nice acidity ensure there’s no heavy oakness. The cellar master told me he enjoyed a lot making this vintage, and I do believe it. The soft, silky tannins wrap around the palate like a delicate web, charming us without needing intense depth. The finish surprises with a touch of salinity, adding a complexity that sandy clay soils typically don’t offer.

name: 2016 Chateau Montlabert
text: Medium bodied, elegant, round and forward, there is some oak that needs to integrate before the ripe plums cherries and licorice in this soft textured fruity wine is at its best. 90 Points

name: 2016 Chateau Montlabert
text: 93–95. Barrel Sample. Ripe and juicy, this is a delicious wine. With its bold black fruits and balanced structure, it has all the makings of a ripe and generous yet crisp wine. There is a strong black-currant element here, while the wine finishes with a great lift of juicy acidity.

name: 2016 Chateau Talbot 'Connetable Talbot'
text: This wine is vigorous with a concentrated richness. The succulent waxberries and a gentle fragrance of graphite blend together as a core. After swirling the glass, it releases a light scent of pines and cypresses. Because of gentler maceration and less oaky flavors, this wine offers me beautiful softness and freshness once it touches my palate. It’s a nice choice to share with your friends on the weekend!

name: 2016 Chateau de Carles Haut-Carles
text: Youthful dark inky purple colour. Pure and modern nose with high ripeness displaying fresh blackberry, cherry, fine wood and tobacco. Dense palate with nicely grained tannin, layers of ripe unctuous dark fruit, yet with a nice freshness underneath, fine oak integration and a very long and layered finish, nicely done.

name: 2016 Chateau de Carles Haut-Carles
text: Deep dark ruby, firm core, purple reflections, lighter rim. Aromas of nice ripe cherry fruit, with dark berry in the background, and a delicate nougat touch. Juicy palate, good complexity, pleasant freshness, fine well-integrated tannins, a mineral salty finish, and very promising.

name: 2016 Chateau de Carles Haut-Carles
text: Haut-Carles 2016 is my best vintage before the evolution of the vinification method (the last vintage to make Integral Fermentation). The palate is saturated with graphite, concentrated, sleek, offering metallic brilliance. The nose is embraced with rich yet not flamboyant fruitiness like Chinese salty prune and Tamarind Pulp. Thanks to the high acidity, this wine keeps its freshness from start to finish.

name: 2017 Chateau Boutisse
text: Chateau Boutisse 2017 came to me wrapped in hawthorn and licorice. Although the aromatic intensity of this vintage was not high, the aromatic line was delicate, with a pleasing hint of beef jerky and chalk ash on the finish, along with a few lingering full-bodied notes. Marc, the owner of the winery, told me that Chateau Boutisse was affected by the frost in the 2017 vintage and that production was very limited.

name: 2017 Chateau Clos Saint Martin
text: Black cherries, licorice, espresso and fudge are the first thing you'll notice. From there, you'll quickly move to the creamy, silky textures, lush, polished tannins and the decadently ripe, dark fruits and espresso-filled finish.

name: 2017 Chateau Clos Saint Martin
text: Clos Saint Martin 2017 may not exhibit a complex bouquet, but it exudes an exquisite charm. The fragrances of cherry and blackberry are remarkably distinct, devoid of any traces of high oak barrel fermentation (Integral Fermentation). Additionally, for the first time in the estate’s history, they employed amphoras for aging (20-25%). According to my tasting, it was evident that aside from rendering the wine’s structure more velvety, this choice accentuated the chalky tannins on the finish, making them more lucid. In contrast to some 2017 vintage wines that lacked concentration, Clos Saint Martin boasts a richness that doesn’t pale in comparison to its grander vintages. After conversing with the winemaking team, it was revealed that late harvest was the key to the success of Clos Saint Martin 2017 (risking gray rot, they began harvesting in early October).

name: 2017 Chateau Croix de Labrie
text: Croix de Labrie 2017 mainly features coffee and black chocolate aromas, with hints of familiar ripe berries. The acidity is pretty high on the entry of the palate, with powder tannins from head to toes. Even if this winery suffered spring frost in this vintage, the winemaker Axelle still handled the character of this wine very well.

name: 2017 Chateau Croix de Labrie
text: Youthful as you would expect, the wine is on the fresh, bright, red fruit side with soft, polished tannins and a nice sweetness to the fruits. The oak is close to fully integrated, allowing you to savor all the sweet, ripe, red pit fruits and berries. Still, this is quite primary, so give it at least 5 years of cellaring before popping a bottle.

name: 2017 Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou
text: "Great producer from an rather difficult vintage lovely nose packed with red and black fruit but also cedaroak , smoek and graphite well balanced , tannins are soft and fully integrated good to drink now 93/100"

name: 2017 Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou
text: Deep dark ruby, purple reflections, delicate brightening on the rim. Intense dark berry fruit on the nose with hints of cassis and blackberry, fresh orange zest and a mineral touch. Taut palate, ripe cherry fruit, vivid, still demanding tannins and a long finish with more black cherry and red berries. A savoury food wine showing some development, but with definite ageing potential.

name: 2017 Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou
text: While the dense and dark tannins are prominent, they can't mask the exuberant fruit that wants to burst out. Blackberry flavors are impressively ripe and rich, shot through with acidity that gives the wine salinity as well as freshness. At the back, those tannins will allow the wine to age over many years. Don't drink before 2024. Roger Voss

name: 2017 Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou
text: As I tasted Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou 2017 after a four-year time, my conviction grew stronger—the Medoc’s Left Bank of the 2017 vintage has been gravely underestimated. In terms of the opulence of its fruit aromas, the 2017 vintage displays remarkable maturity and a soothing allure. Beyond the luscious notes of ripe mulberries and blackberries, there exists an authentic infusion of mocha, fresh green peppercorns, and a delicate hint of pine. Compared to those vintages characterized by exuberant fruit fragrances, Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou 2017 embodies a discernible essence of traditional Bordeaux charm. The discreet touch of “sweetness” that adorns the finish is artfully woven, leaving a lasting impression of the wine’s tender and affectionate salutation.

name: 2017 Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou
text: Freshness and accessibility are the hallmarks of this wine. The customary level of density is improved with added grace, elegance, pliability and an upbeat, spicy core of attention seeking fruits. This is not to say that the wine is light. It is to explain that power has been refined with approachability, brighter fruits and exceedingly silky tannins. The wine was made from a blend of 90% Cabernet Sauvignon and 10% Merlot and is aging in 100% new, French oak barrels. The wine reached 13.51% alcohol with a pH of 3.79. The harvest took place from September 18 to September 30.

name: 2017 Chateau Saint-Pierre
text: Fresh and bright, with a focus on its red fruits, peppery nuances, espresso and herbs. You also find a nice shot of tobacco and cedar. The wine is wine is round, forward, medium-bodied and with just a few years in the cellar, it should be ready to get going. 92 Points

name: 2017 Chateau Saint-Pierre
text: 2017 marked Chateau Saint-Pierre’s second trial with the whole bunch fermentation (which accounted for a very small part of the blend). While nearly no signs of whole bunch fermentation are detectable in the 2016 vintage, it is a masterstroke on the 2017, somewhat resembling the aged Chinese Pu-Erh tea. Different from the freshness presented in the same vintage, Chateau Saint-Pierre 2017 exhibits attractive structure, it is a good example of a good value Pomerol in 2017.

name: 2017 Le Macchiole 'Paleo' Bolgheri
text: In the dry and hot vintage like 2017, Paelo seems to have less liveliness comparing with its iconic image. Although the fruity fragrance is still precise, and the herbal scent of Balsamic remains fresh, its structure and strength do go beyond the aesthetic limits of Cabernet Franc in my mind. Medium/full-bodied, fresh, vibrant, clean and pure, the fruit offers length, depth and complexity. But it will need a bit of time to fully express its essence. If you have a bit of patience, it will be worth the wait. Drink from 2030-2060. 97 Points

name: 2019 Chateau Rauzan-Segla
text: Rauzan-Segla 2019 is a sublime and gorgeous top-quality Margaux. The aromas are arresting and elegant, just one sniff seems to lead you in a floral world covered with violet. The palate is fresh and juicy, soft and refined, with the scent of cumin and fennel lingering on your taste buds, accompanied by creamy and fine-grained tannins, which is like a furry Persian carpet emitting the fragrance of oriental spices. Absolutely a noble and sublime feast for tasting.

name: 2019 Chateau Rochebelle
text: A fresh and elegant wine that delights people very well. The floral scent is particularly prominent, feeling like a basket of roses turned over in a cup. With its creamy, delicate tannins and compact finish, this wine is worth trying for lovers of the style of natural purity.

name: 2019 Chateau Saint-Georges Cote Pavie
text: Just a sniff is good enough to blow my mind. The scent of rose essence is so enticing, leaving people hanging on every sip. The entry of the palate is precise, delicate and bouncy, with a pure blackberry, mulberry and milk-like creamy taste. The tannins are abundant, but its texture is as velvet as cashmere; when it flows on the taste buds, it seems that you could hear the sound of rattling. Such a luscious and elegant wine is a salute to the terroir of Saint-Emilion.

answer: flower, licorice, espresso bean, black cherry and plum
name: 2019 Chateau Saint-Georges Cote Pavie
text: Much better in the bottle than it was from the barrel, the wine pops with nuances of flowers, licorice, espresso bean, black cherry and black plum. Rich, round, soft, and polished, the finish is loaded with silky textured fruits with a nice touch of salty-minerality on the finish. Drink from 2023-2034. 91 Points

name: 2019 Chateau Saint-Georges Cote Pavie
text: Floral and perfumed with chalky notes, darker fruit, violet tobacco leaf and fine oak. Good density and harmony with a fresh backbone, an abundance of really grainy tannin, layers of ripe dark fruit and a long vigorous finish.

name: 2019 Chateau Tour St Joseph
text: The nose is as rich as a sweet Candy, giving off dried blackberries, crushed blueberries and a slice of honeyed ginger. The mouth is supple and plump; the mellow taste emerges from the inside out with soft tannins and a juicy texture.

text: The genial aroma is filled with succulent ripe fruit aromas, while the melodious blueberry fragrance and sweet cream cherry are particularly solid with the help of a compact mineral notes. The softness on the palate is like fresh milk flowing through the taste buds, showing me a pleasant and elegant personality characteristic, exuding “sense of natural” from the inside out.

You can enjoy this on release or age it a few years before opening a bottle. de Ferrand has been kicking up the quality here over the past few years, which is nice to see. Drink from 2022-2035. 91 Points

blackberry, plum and blueberry
licorice and cinnamon
name: 2019 Chateau de Malleret
text: The aromas are pretty intense, it can be seen that the maturity of their grapes is exceptional. The scents of blackberry, plum and blueberry jam become more enticing through the decoration of licorice and cinnamon. The powdery tannins are rich and robust, but thanks to the juicy and translucent mouth feeling, the entire body maintains balanced until the end.

name: 2019 Chateau de Malleret
text: In the southern Haut-Médoc, this 133-acre estate devoted to horse riding has produced a rich wine that has both density and impressive black fruits. With concentration and a core of tannins, the wine has great potential. Drink from 2026. Roger Voss

name: 2019 Chateau de Malleret
text: « Darkly coloured with young, vibrant red reflections. Intense nose with fruit tones underscored by elegant oakiness. The same noble structure and aromas flow through to the palate. A wine with good breed and undeniable potential. »

name: 2019 Clos des Lunes 'Lune d'Argent'
text: Pale lemon yellow colour with greenish hints. Lovely, classic aromas of asparagus, pea-pod & cats-pee with sulphide notes. The palate is dry, soft & rounded with ripe fruit & balanced alcohol - acid is a little low & the finish of mid-length. 6/20 DCAMW

name: 2019 Clos des Lunes 'Lune d'Argent'
text: With a high proportion of Sémillon in the blend, this is a ripe, creamy wine. It has a background tang of acidity, with citrus a focus initially. As the wine matures further, the richness and yellow-fruit flavors will come through strongly. Drink from 2023. Roger Voss

name: 2019 Clos des Lunes 'Lune d'Argent'
text: As a Semillon-based white wine, I can feel its roundness and sweetness through a candy-like flavor. Its salty mineral notes improve the tension and clarity towards the finish. As an easy-drinking wine, it is very suitable for sharing with friends during summertime.

answer:
peach and apricot
jackfruit and bergamot
name: 2019 Le Clementin du Chateau Pape Clement
text: The nose features ripe yellow peach and apricots, with hints of jackfruit and bergamot after swirling the glass. The round body and oily made me mistakenly think it was a high proportion of Semillon blend (78% Sauvignon Blanc); it explains well the charisma of white wine in a hot and ripe vintage.

name: 2019 Le Clementin du Chateau Pape Clement
text: Sweet and smoky with tobacco leaf, espresso, lead pencil and ripe, dark red berry notes create the aromatic profile. On the palate, the wine is soft, round, polished, sweet and fruity. There is lift, character and a load of ripe red berries in the finish. Enjoy this while waiting for the Grand Vin to develop. Drink from 2023-2034. 91 Points

name: 2019 Michel & Stephane Ogier Cote Rotie La Belle Helene
text: La Belle Helene 2019 has an energy that lights up the whole world, and it is hard to imagine that such a colorful wine can maintain such a refined aromatic line. How brilliant it is effortlessly! Aromas of violets and roses, juicy berry fruit are light and elegant against the smooth acidity. With the silky tannins throughout, it’ll make you feel so refreshing that you won’t believe your mouth!

name: 2019 Michel & Stephane Ogier Cote Rotie La Belle Helene
text: Dark in color, the wine displays a smoke-filled perfume packed with spice, black cherries blackberries, flowers, and crushed stone. The wine stains your palate with its layers of ripe, polished, elegant, energetic, vibrant fruits. Full-bodied with a serious depth of flavor, and purity to the fruits, this stunning wine will age for 3 decades with ease. The seamless finish hangs with you for 60 seconds, or longer. The fruit comes from 2 parcels on the Cote Rozier, with one parcel just below La Landonne. The grapes are whole bunch fermented and aged in an average of 15% new, French oak for the first year before being moved to demi-muids for the second year of aging. Drink from 2030-2055.

name: 2019 Moulin du Cadet
text: The nose is clear and racy, delivering bright cherry, blueberry, and plentiful spicy notes. The entry is smooth and straightforward, brimming with sweet dark fruits and plenty of toasty notes. The alcohol is well maintained, without any heaviness. If had more nuances of complexity in the finish, it would be much more prominent.

name: 2019 Moulin du Cadet

name: 2019 Ornellaia 'Le Volte dell'Ornellaia' Toscana IGT
text: Thanks to the low-temperature maceration, the floral and fruity aromas of this wine are particularly lively, cherished with juicy jujube and sour plum on the palate. As an entry-level wine of the entire family of Ornellaia, based on highlighting elegance, it always demonstrates the classic aesthetic principle of Ornellaia: BALANCE. If the tannins become calmer on the finish, this wine will be more adorable.

name: 2019 Pavillon Rouge du Chateau Margaux
text: The wine is rich, open and generous. The bold black fruits mask the tannins and bring out the fine balance between structure and fruit. Drink this very fine wine from 2026. Roger Voss

name: 2019 Pavillon Rouge du Chateau Margaux
text: Absolutely penetrating, the aromas of pure, delicate spices and fresh berries flow out of the glass, which is dynamic and solid, intricate and fragrant. It is as soft and mushy as rice dumplings on the palate, accompanied by tense structure and slender lines that attack your taste buds. The whole tasting process is smooth and fluid, and this is one of the most lively Pavillon Rouge in recent vintages.

name: 2020 Chateau Beauvillage
text: With its silky tannins, crystal-clear palate, and light floral aroma, this Medoc wine is the perfect choice for a relaxing drink. I particularly appreciate its sweet and juicy notes of rhubarb jam and the spicy undertones of licorice that blend seamlessly with the wine’s soft body, making every sip a warm and enjoyable experience.

name: 2020 Chateau Canon-Chaigneau

answer: rose, plum, and licorice and pepper
name: 2020 Chateau Caronne Ste Gemme

Suggested drinking window: 2024-2030.

name: 2020 Chateau Clarke
text: Chewy, leafy, savory, earthy, chalky currants with leafy accents and a hint of spice is what you will find in the nose and on the medium-bodied, fresh, earthy, classic, slightly rustic palate. Drink from 2023-2038.

answer: prune, blackberry, pepper, violet, peel and coriander
name: 2020 Chateau Clarke

name: 2020 Chateau Clarke
text: A grand vintage for this Edmond de Rothschild family-owned estate. The wine is rich, powerfully textured. It is solid with tannins that are considerable to balance the black fruits. This will age many years, drink from 2027.

name: 2020 Chateau Clarke

The nice blueberries and raspberries are still readily apparent, despite the fruit not being as crisp and sweet as in the 2019 vintage. Even with a large sip, there is no heaviness because to the delicate and milky palate. Of course, it would be of Grand Cru caliber if there were additional layers on the finish.

name: 2020 Chateau Doyac
text: This structured, ripe wine comes from the northern part of the Haut-Médoc appellation. It has fine black fruits and rich tannins, both of which are sure to soften as the wine matures further. Drink from 2025. Organic and biodynamic.

Under the creamy tannins, there is a layer of graphite and pencil lead that enhances the flavor without altering it. It should be noted that this biodynamic wine that I appreciate a lot needs to be carafed more frequently when drunk at a young age.

name: 2020 Chateau Fleur La Mothe
text: The defining characteristic of Chateau Fleur La Mothe that sets it apart from other Medoc wines is its impeccable tannin refinement. The velvety texture brings a full-bodied richness to the palate and leaves a remarkable finish. Although the fruit may not be as abundant, the overall experience is truly satisfying. It is suggested to enjoy this wine between 2023 and 2029.

name: 2020 Chateau Grand-Pontet
text: Medium-bodied, with notes of wet earth, espresso, licorice, dark red berries and cocoa on the nose. Soft, round, lush and polished, the wine is forward, fruity and a bit oaky at the moment. Give it a few years to come together and it will be an even better wine. 89-91

name: 2020 Chateau Grand-Pontet
text: The juicy entry and bright acidity capture me immediately, but the tannins’ structure still needs to be polished through a period of further aging. The bouquet is brimming with fresh red fruits and distinctive green tea notes, contributing a vibrant freshness from start to finish.

Chateau Grand-Puy Lacoste 2020 boasts the body as silk, and tannins fine as the first-class rouge. Caressing on the palates, it seems wearing a silky garment. Tasting this wine, I was touched for several times; it is unbelieveable that it could accomandate the huge energy of Pauillac in a crystal body, meanwhile sending off fresh and elegant fragrances of rosin, bay leaf and pencil shave. It provides the ideal drinking period as long as 25 years. Sure that every 3 to 5 years, it will give us unique surprises.

Length, purity, complexity and a seemingly, endless, creamy finish caps everything off. This is the finest vintage ever produced at Grand Puy Lacoste. Fans of the estate, and Pauillac should be all over this wine. Drink from 2026-2060.

name: 2020 Chateau Guadet
text: Ripe black plums and licorice define the wines nose. On the palate. you find a soft, ripe, silky, fresh, sweet layer of ripe cherries, coffee and kirsch with dusty tannins. 88-90

name: 2020 Chateau Guadet
text: The estate has evolved considerably, and this latest release continues the development with ripe black fruits and beautifully textured tannins. With its balance and structure, the wine will develop. Drink from 2027. Organic and biodynamic. Multiple U.S. importers.

name: 2020 Chateau Guadet
text: The big oak barrels and amphora aging fully optimize the aromatic expression of Chateau Guadet 2020: blueberries and raspberries are plump, and you can seem to hear the sound of the fruit bursting on the entry of the palate. The chalky texture of the limestone plateau is expressed particularly clearly, covering the surface of the round body, which feels like a lace cloth has been unfolded. It is a great pleasure to taste this wine.

name: 2020 Chateau L'Enclos
text: Chateau l’Enclos 2020 has a natural aroma, with pleasant notes of Dahurian rose and small red fruits. This wine is rounder than the group’s others, with a better mix of toasted and spiced aromas and, while still a little flat in the middle, a good balance on the whole. You can enjoy it without aging.

name: 2020 Chateau L'Isle Fort
text: The fruity aroma is still pure, the body is still pristine, the saltiness is still clear, and the palate is still smooth. Compared with other hot vintages, Chateau l’Isle Fort 2020 has a special “reductive” note, making the line of the fragrance relatively reserved. But with my understanding of this wine, this shy beauty will open its sleepy eyes after 3-5 years of aging. At that time, you will feel like seeing a pure and rippling lake through its pupils.

name: 2020 Chateau L'Isle Fort

name: 2020 Chateau La Clemence

name: 2020 Chateau La Clemence

Mixed with the complex aromas of white pepper, fennel, bay leaf, and grapefruit peel, the wine creates a graceful palate that resembles spicy soup on the taste buds. Coupled with the mild note of fresh and bitter tea stem on the finish, it can steal your heart without you even realizing it.

name: 2020 Chateau La Tour de Bessan
text: What is it like to taste tofu pudding in wine? The 2020 vintage of Chateau La Tour de Bessan gave me the answer to this question. Although the aromas are slightly reserved after bottling, the fragrance of fresh fruit and petals slowly unfolds on the entry of the palate. I love those tannins hidden in the round body, for they show a “beautiful shyness”.

name: 2020 Chateau Lafon-Rochet
text: The softness of the 2020 vintage made me start to re-examine the traditional image of Chateau Lafon-Rochet. The powerful tannins nurtured by clay soil naturally become tightly knit and soft, and both the gentle palate and the smooth body show the winemaker’s profound understanding of the extraction process. Behind the notes of ripe black plum and blackcurrant hides a mild scent of hazelnut and fried melon seeds, and although the fragrance of this wine is not complex, it inspires my imagination of its performance after bottle aging. It is highly recommended to focus on Chateau Lafon-Rochet from now on because as the dry and hot weather appears more and more frequently, the terroir features of its clay may bring us unexpected surprises.

answer: Flowers, cigar wrapper, wet earth, smoke, chocolate, blackberry
name: 2020 Chateau Lafon-Rochet
text: Flowers, cigar wrapper, wet earth, smoke, chocolate, blackberries and red pit fruits open the nose. But, it is on the palate, where the wine really shines with all of its layers of full-bodied, concentrated, long, dark, round, energetic, creamy, plush, ripe, fruits. The finish is long, clean and vibrant with a creamy textured endnote that will be even better once the minor amount of oak remaining has fully integrated. This is the final vintage from the Tesseron family who brought in the harvest and vinified the wine. The new owner, Jacky Lorenzetti, along with Emmanuel Cruse finished the wine. Starting with the 2021 vintage, the new owners were fully in charge. Drink from 2024-2045.
